author: murdozzz

title: Armattan Chameleon RX Antenna Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These mounts are intended to be clipped under the back arms of the Armattan Chameleon frame to hold 3mm antenna tubes, into which you can put your whip antennas so that they don't get chopped by the propellers.

At first i had my antennas sticking out the back in a 90° angle, but they were so long that whenever the back of the quad hit the ground a bit too steep, the tubes and antennas would still get chopped because they flexed into the the props. By routing them under the arms back to the front, they should never be in any danger, as they are situated between the arms and should never touch the ground. They are in a 90° angle (or close to it, i haven't actually meassured, but it looks good enough), so your diversity will work as intended.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 should be fine

Print the STL as it is, then put the antenna tube into the mount before clipping it to the arm. This makes it a lot easier to push it through, in case it catches on the edge of the hole on the other side.
When inserting your whip antenna, make sure that the unshielded tip does not protrude from the front of the antenna tube - this is the actual antenna part, so it should be well protected.

author: jangrewe

title: Extreme Bow Stabilizer - VERSION 2 AVAILABLE NOW - Customizable!

description.text:
VERSION 2 IS AVAILABLE HERE: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463721

This bow stabilizer was inspired by this one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1152975

I wanted to create a simpler version of the bow stabilizer, that still retains it looks, and functionality. This version of the stabilizer will save you a lot of print time, and material. By using 4 used/old/found arrow shafts, this project will cost you only about $5.

3D Parts needed:

  • 1x Receiver (1.25" OR 2")
  • Rail (Need 1. Print as many as you would like)
  • 1x Barrel
  • 1x Flashhider OR Silencer (Optional, but it adds on to the looks of it.)

Parts required to assemble:

  • 4x 7.8mm Arrow shafts
  • 1x UNF 5/16*24 1.25" OR 5/16-24 2" bolt
  • 1x M8 washer
  • 1x M8 nut
  • 1x M10 90mm
  • 4x M10 nuts

Assembly instructions:
(Notice! You may need to use a 5/16" drill bit to expand the arrow slots. If too loose, use silicone glue or hot glue to secure everything in place.)

  1. Receiver: If you printed the 1.25" or the 2" version, make sure your 5/16-24 bolt match accordingly. Place an M8 washer into the bottom(Square indent), and slide a bolt down through it. Secure it using an M8 bolt.
  2. Barrel & Flash hider: Insert the M10 90mm bolt from the bottom square face of the barrel. Secure it at the top with an M10 nut. Place up to 3 more M10 nuts at the end to increase weight
  3. Insert arrow shafts into the receiver.
  4. Slide rail(s) down the arrow shafts to align the arrows.
  5. Place barrel over the other end of the arrow shafts.
  6. Pressure fit muzzle device over barrel.

Printer:

MPSM V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15-100%

Drill out the arrow slots

You may find that the arrow slots are too small to put the arrows through. If that is the case, use a 5/16" drill bit to expand the holes. The arrows should not be able to be pressure fit into the stabilizer.

Glue

If the parts are too loose, I would recommend using silicone glue, or hot glue, to secure the parts. The good thing about these glues are that they are relatively sturdy, but you can take them apart if you want to reuse the pieces.

author: fats699

title: Chair Spine for Broken Hydraulics
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's my tale in bullet points:

  • Bought a chair to support up to 400lbs.
  • I weight 320.
  • Hydraulics lasted 3.5 years, died a month or two back.
  • Bought replacement. Lasted a month and change.
  • Can't get replacement off.
  • Printed this set of interlocking vertebrae and cushions.

They work pretty well for my chair so far. You may want to scale up or down depending on your chair, these print as-is with a diameter of 38.5mm.

The A and B pieces interlock, and have tolerance at about 0.3mm. This can be printed in PLA, but I recommend ABS or PETG above all else. About 15% infill should be fine, if you can do the tetra-infill from Cura, I'd go with that maybe.

The Cushion piece I printed in Ninjaflex, and I'd recommend that or another very flexible (not semi) material. That may be printed at about 15-30% infill. I went with 20.

Holds up well so far :)

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini V1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15-30%

Notes:

The Cushion piece I printed in Ninjaflex, and should be a flex material.
The A and B pieces interlock, and I recommend ABS or PETG above all else.

author: Brad_Blazer

title: Flexible Mounting Hooks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a derivative of the kind of flexible hooks you may see in the organization section of a store. Modeled from scratch.

The "Egg" or main mounting body I'd recommend printing in PLA or ABS in 100% infill. and is easy enough with no supports needed.

The flex part on the other hand... Well that's tricky. You have two or three options:

  1. Print the entire thing in one piece. I didn't test if this could be done with no supports. But when you use flex material like ninjaflex, it's pretty darn hard to remove. Had to toss it away. If you can howere, I'd recommend that (say if you printer can print separate support material, or you have a technique for flex stuff). Then adhere it to the slot on the egg, more on that later.

  2. Print the ones in parts, and stick them together. I'm not sure what works well for ninjaflex, but I heard, "not much", so used the same method I used for adhering it to the egg. More on that next. (Though, I'm sure something like Gorilla Glue may work well...).

So how did I adhere it all? I used a heat gun. I melted down the two parts of the flex hook part and stuck them together when they were nice and gooey looking. Then, to the egg I applied some crazy glue and I heated the flex material to gooey and stuck them together. Crazy glue may not have been needed, but still.

Of course the hook part was also printed with 100% infill and standard settings for ninjaflex.

The backing will still need adhesive to your wall.... so do that as you see fit. I bought a 20-pack of command adhesive strips for this and other store hooks.

title: Anet A8/A6 Heatbed GoPro Bracket Mount (Two Sizes!)

description.text:
This is my own design for a simple, easy to use and easy to attach and detach mount for my GoPro. It attaches directly to the heated bed via one of the front screws and can be fastened with the wing nuts that come with the printer. As opposed to most other mounts, this one offers a GoPro bracket mount instead of a screw attachment.

It comes in two sizes. V5 places the camera around 92mm from the screw mount while V6 places it only 20mm away. I recommend printing V6 laying flat on the 45 degree back without supports.

During the print, the mount doesn't jiggle or wobble at all thanks to the support struts and it helps to produce time-lapses where the print is stationary in the frame. Here's an example:
https://youtu.be/FQbpD7YRkzM

If this Thing helped you out, a tip would be much appreciated!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

V5: Supports might be necessary for the bracket up top. If you can use selective supports, you should put support inside the bracket but it's not needed anywhere else.

V6: Print rotated at 45 degrees laying flat on build plate entirely without support.

title: Space Saver Bag Vacuum Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like the ziploc space saver bags, gneerally (they can be a bit easy to tear imo). But I could never get my vacuum to fit it's hose on the suction hole.

I made this part, in two parts, to help in that.

The main body may be printed in whatever you like, least shrinkage is better at about 15% infill is enough.
The base piece I printed in a flex material, Ninjaflex, at 100% infill and recommended settings.

I attached them together by the groove I made and placing a bit of gorilla glue around the inside of the base and applied weight/pressure to the two pieces for an hour while it dried.

The adapter's diameter is 16mm. Scale as needed. If I can learn later, may make a customizer...

title: Enclosure joint for foam board enclosure

description.text: I whipped this up in fusion 360 for an enclosure to hold my printer. As I am 13, I didn't have much to play around with so I went to Walmart and bought some foam boards because I figured if foam is used for insulation, wouldn't it be good enclosure material?(plus they were only like 3 bucks each) This joint will tightly hold foam boards together so they meet in a corner. I printed 8 of them (one for each corner of the enclosure) and then simply cut a foam board to fit on top. Very cheap solution for a decent enclosure. The best part about this is you can tear it down in minutes. This is really long. In your slicer cut it down so it only 65mm tall.

author: mduperly001

description.text:
I've looked on Thingiverse to see if anyone has uploaded the Dalek Gun.
But all I was the rear and front assembly.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1773733
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1772511

This isn't a remix just an update.
I could of went with standard rods "Arrow Rods" but then I would of paid between $2 and $5 per rod and I need 8.
This way I can print each rod for about $.05 cents.
In the long run it would of been cheaper, Pay for arrow rods and gas, this way I saved money.
The update are the clear tubes, They will light up with L.E.D. lights
Once I get that done I will post some pictures. but until then enjoy.

8/20/2017: Updated look of the inner Gun Tube with L.E.D. lights for 7 different color gun settings. The new items are the L.E.D. holder. The Holder is hollow so you can insert a tube to add a smoke machine or use a E-Cig to blow smoke out of the gun.
There are L.E.D. Spacers to align the L.E.D. holder center in the Gun Tube, After you glue spaces in then you must pour clear Epoxy Resin in the Gun tube to make sure the L.E.D.s stay secure n the tube. Plus the clear Epoxy will allow the L.E.D.s to spread their light though out the tube for major lighting effect.
After it all dries there will be 3 buttons per light to allow 7 different color changes for different levels of simulated gun fire.

I was able to complete my Dalek Gun. Now all I got to do is mount it and it will be ready.

Waiting on my 400 watt mini smoke machine to arrive so I can attach that to it.

description.text: replacement snap on skids for an Apple Magic Mouse.

The surface of my desk must be rough because the black skids on the bottom of my mouse wear down over time.  So much so that eventually the aluminum body of the mouse is rubbing on my desk.  (making a horrible noise)  This is a printable solution to this problem. These skids snap around the existing skids and raise the mouse up to a normal level without interfering in the function or feel of the mouse.
Update:  I recently purchased a magic mouse 2 so I would not have to keep replacing batteries all the time.  I discovered that they changed the spacing and size of the skids slightly, so I've uploaded a new version of files for this mouse as well.

This is a mash up of @guohc's Nerf rail adapter and @kaiyote's Nerf Rival Tactical Rail. My son accidentally bought a Nerf Rival accessory, but due to new Rival rail type it doesn't fit his Nerf Elite. description.text:
Minor tweak to orginial Prusa i3 Hephestos BLTouch Auto Leveling Mount.
The mount was to high for the infitary m508, so i added a little bit of material for height (about 5.7mm) so it falls into the Bltouch 8mm difference in height between nozzle and bottom of bltouch (Not including metal pin).

For more information on how to setup the BLtouch on a Infitary prusa I3 m508, go here;
http://bizinno.blogspot.co.nz/2017/07/setting-up-bltouch-on-infitary-m508.html

Other dock cases I'd seen on Thingiverse and whatnot left the USB-C connector exposed, which just didn't jive with me. Also, with no cord, there's a rigid connection between the "dock" and console, another downside for me.

So I designed my own. This case places the USB connector deep inside the case, well protected. It's designed to be used with this USB-C extension cord but could be adjusted to fit others (it's purposefully a slightly snug fit).

https://www.amazon.com/dp/B071JTX91K/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apap_DVMqUbswp7xdh

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

It's designed to be able to press-fit together with no fasteners. Two short M3 screws and nuts will hold it together more reliably. Depending on your print quality/settings some light sanding may be required to get all the pieces to fit. View the Fusion 360 link below for better angles for assembly.
Feel free to view/download/remix the Fusion 360 design: http://a360.co/2u8ulzA

I set my Makerbot Mini to 4 shells @ 25% infill for dependable durability on the shaft. Especially if the PRVC motorized volume control is fitted.

Note this version is 4mm shorter than the one shown in the photo as it will fit the hole in the rear cover better.

title: Playstation Eye Camera mount for Prusa i3 Mk2

description.text:
A friction fit mount for the PS3 Eye camera. These are pretty cheap (~$4 on ebay) and somewhat decent cameras for the money. This mount is meant to slide under the heated bed and zip tie into place. The camera slides into the mount and should stay put without any problems. There is some flex to this part (even before I put the cut-outs in) but it takes great time lapse:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qwa4n7HM1-A

Sliced with Simplify3D, I would suggest supports at all of the overhangs. You might be able to get away with without it, but it won't be pretty.

description.text:
These simple cat and dog device stands are a quick print (2-3hrs) and a fun addition to any animal lover's desk. The device holding portion of them (tail/lower back) are identical so they can be mixed and matched (dog/dog, cat/cat, dog/cat)

title: Replicator+ Secondary Filament Feed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This Spool Holder is made specifically for the MakerBot Replicator+. It installs in a matter of seconds by hanging on the rear of the machine (refer images) and has a tab to hold it in position so it can't slide across the back of the machine during printing.

Having a second spool installed while printing makes mid-print color changes much quicker and easier... because the second color spool is already loaded. Just pause your Rep+, unload the filament, reload filament feeding from the alternative spool / system and resume. No more opening up the draw and physically changing spools mid-print to create multi-colour prints.

This spool holder has been designed to allow alternative 3rd Party spools of different sizes to be fitted / used. It will accept spools of up to 250mm diameter, 57mm wide and with a core size of greater than 52mm. This will work with many but not all brands.

Note: MakerBot genuine filament is manufactured to a very high standard so provides reliable printing. Take care if using 3rd party filament as low quality filament can cause print reliability and quality issues as well as damage your extruder.

A Guide Tube Link file is also provided. This attaches to both guide tubes to ensure the secondary guide tube running from the rear of the machine follows a similar path to the extruder as the original guide tube.

The Spool Holder surface is ribbed to reduce friction so the spool will rotate smoothly and easily with minimal drag.

This system is easy to print, install and use. The only things to be specially aware of are:

(1) The drawer will not slide up when the secondary / rear Spool Holder is installed. If you want to change the spool in the drawer just life the rear spool holder off its mounting position and sit it behind the machine in a position that keeps the still connected guide tube clear of the drawer. No problem to do this... you just need to get the rear holder away from the drawer.

(2) Make sure the Guide Tube not in use is positioned around the side of the machine and away from all moving parts so it cannot interfere during printing... but remains quickly accessible for filament color changes.

This is a simple solution that makes using a Replicator+ in a creative way easier plus opens up alternative filament colors and types.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

PLA / 3 Shells / 35% infill or more... to make it strong and support the weight of a full spool.

Notes:

Use 3 shells and higher than normal infill to ensure the spool holder is strong and will hold the weight of a full / heavy spool.

No support required. Raft recommended.

Quick and easy to install...

The only additional item required is a second Filament Guide Tube. Buying a genuine MakerBot guide tube is recommended (as the fitting on the spool holder is designed to accept the standard diameter tube). If you use a third party guide tube make sure it is of a high quality with minimal internal resistance and the same sizing (internal and external) and length as the original.

Once you have another guide tube this is quick and easy to install and use.

title: Another Y tensioner for AM8 frame

description.text:
Updates 17/09/2017
Uploaded a shorter version, since it makes no sense that the "U" part is so long.
This version requires a slightly longer Y belt.

Updates 16/08/2017
Removed most of the play along Z in Y Tensioner Case. The other two pieces remain the same.

This is a different Y belt tensioner for AM8 frame. Works with the original Y stepper mount, so it is fully compatible with stock AM8 by pheneeny.
I made myself this one, which is more rigid and has almost no play around Z axis, it just lets move back and forth, unlike many tensioners based on two bolts and/or two sections.

It should have approx 5mm stroke, which is more than enough to give the belt that last bit of tension. Should work with toothed idler mod. Added a cutaway view to see the assembly more clearly.

ASSEMBLY:
-M4x24mm hex bolt
-M4 nut
-5 or 6mm diameter (20-25mm long spring)
-M3x24mm allen bolt
-M3 nut
-M3 washers (optional, but highly recommendable between moving and stationary parts, and also between bolts/nuts and 3d printed parts)

title: Miniature Force Multiplier, Medium Size
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like to use miniatures in my games of Dungeons & Dragons, and admittedly, I have quite a few of them. Even so, when it comes time to hunt down the player characters with an entire gnoll war band, it can be hard to come up with six gnashers, 4 slashers, a dozen bipedal hyenas, and a partridge in a pear tree... thus I created the Force Multiplier. Use one miniature to designate an entire squad of baddies, all color coordinated. Now for less than a dollar I have sextupled my forces.

I print mine in different colors of filament but I imagine one could just as easily paint them up.
BaseInsert and OriginBand are designed to fit on the base of a medium sized creature from the official DnD miniatures lines. Custom bases should be easy enough to develop.

description.text: Made a basic replacement head for a friend whose flip key broke. I've tested it on a Kia flip key. The blade will be off center slightly but it isn't that noticeable. The fit was tight. I ended up filing it down on the edges of the blade to give it a rough surface and then used a torch to heat up the key blade. I then tapped the heated blade into the replacement key head and it doesn't move or wiggle. I tried to pull it out with my hand and it wouldn't budge. The key ring hole is a little close to the edge for my comfort but after attaching a ring and pulling on it, didn't even fatigue the plastic. I printed it in PLA but if you plan on leaving it somewhere hot, might want to use ABS or better material.

Notes:

The buttons in the photos were printed with a 0.4mm nozzle. I used 0.1mm layer height, and either 0.1 or 0.2mm width (most were 0.2mm). It was an experiment to see what resolution I could get from this nozzle - it would be perfectly fine to use other settings. Prints with no supports.

title: Vacuum Ejector
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a vacuum ejector designed for compressed air to vacuum generation. Advantages of this type of vacuum generation is that it is instant when compressed air is applied it starts generating vacuum. Also, it can handle contaminants in the vacuum flow. As long as the contaminants being ingested in the vacuum port are smaller that the mixing tube diameter (3mm in this case) the ejector will not be blocked.

The input port injects compressed air that is exhausted on the output port. Air in the mixing chamber is entrained in the flow and a vacuum is developed. I have measured 18.5" of mercury (-9PSI) on the vacuum port with 0 flow. I don't have a flow gauge so I can't judge efficiency or flow with an open input.

Graphs with the input pressure and vacuum achieved are attached.

Both the compressed air input and vacuum ports are designed to be tapped with a 1/4" NPT thread. The wall taper matches the NPT thread and allows easy connection to air fittings.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Using Simplify3d variable thin wall extrusion can help print quality with the fine features. A minimum of 1.6mm wall thickness is needed to avoid the NPT tap from breaking through.

This design was based of research on steam ejectors and air vacuum generators. There is little useful documentation on the design of these I have found. There were three previous version that did not perform as well (max 5" of Hg) before I looked at steam ejectors.

The main improvement is the ratio between the expansion tube and the length of the expansion tube. The initial designs had short expansion tubes, but a ratio of 7 for the expansion tube diameter to length greatly improved things.

Since this design tops out at ~75psi, I suspect that I need to look at the mixing tube diameter to prevent supersonic flow. This should improve performance at higher input pressures.

title: Heat-Fit Bike Brake Cable Housing/Hydraulic Line Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a cable housing or hydraulic line guide for a bicycle. It is intended to be heat-fit to the bike to fit the diameter of the tube it's being strapped to for a perfect fit.

This is designed for a 5mm hydraulic line, but I'm sure other diameters will work as well since it's open-ended. The outer two holes are for zip-tying the guide to the bike frame, and the middle hole is for securing the housing/line. The guide may slide on the frame some, depending on how tight the zip-ties are. If this is the case, a rubber back or a dab of hot glue will help increase friction and hold it in place.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this in PETG for better temperature resistance over PLA for hot days with the bike on the back of my car, but I don't think this is entirely necessary as the part's zip tied to the frame and line. I'm sure ABS would work fine as well.

Heat-Fit the Part:

To fit this part to the frame, heat the flat, backside with a hair dryer or heat gun to the point that the plastic starts to warp a little, and then contour it to the frame where you want to mount the guide. DO THIS WITH THICK GLOVES ON! THE PART WILL BE HOT!!! Avoid over heating the part; you just want it pliable, not melting.

You only need to hold it on for 10 to 20 seconds. The part should cool enough to hold its shape fairly quickly. After it's cool you can zip-tie it in place using the outer two holes.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the Pivots, Bolts and Nuts at 100% infill to make them stronger with all of them straight up with only supports touching bed.  I tried with full supports and ended up doing a lot of work on the Threads on the bolts afterwards.  The Pivots and the Nut was printed with no supports with good results.  The Pivots I printed scaled to 96% but kept the length at 100% to get them to fit snugly.  Depending on the resolution your printer you may need to adjust this scale.  The Bottom was printed with no supports and the Window was printed with supports.  At full size it will just fit to print on a 200 mm by 200 mm print bed.  I printed mine on an Anet A8.

description.text: My wife and I love nautical decorations. I was looking around for a Porthole model on various sites that offered 3D models and came up empty. At that point I decided to make my own. I designed this model in Fusion 360. It is a standard 2 Dog porthole. All parts are 3D printed. I printed it in PLA. There is a lip around the window in which you can place a 128 mm round piece of glass or plexi glass.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the Pivots, Bolts and Nuts at 100% infill to make them stronger with all of them straight up with only supports touching bed. I tried with full supports and ended up doing a lot of work on the Threads on the bolts afterwards. The Pivots and the Nut was printed with no supports with good results. The Pivots I printed scaled to 96% but kept the length at 100% to get them to fit snugly. Depending on the resolution your printer you may need to adjust this scale. The Bottom was printed with no supports and the Window was printed with supports. At full size it will just fit to print on a 200 mm by 200 mm print bed. I printed mine on an Anet A8.

description.text:
My son wanted to use these angel eyes (60mm) for a reading light:

https://www.superbrightleds.com/moreinfo/led-headlight-accent-lights/rgb-led-angel-eye-headlight-accent-light-kits/628/

I liked doctriam's adjustable wall-mount, so I decided to remove the magnet-holding portion of his design and bolt on a custom holder for two angel eyes.

Printer:

Marvin Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I used Hatchbox PETG for all the parts to make sure it had strength (and it's what was already loaded into my printer :D).

I wanted something that would hold it securely, but didn't need any screws to hold the LED rings into place. So, I designed a flexure to hold them in, and it works beautifully! I added additional holes along the top and bottom for a lamp shade if me or my son decides it's needed. If i think of it, I'll update this with pictures of it mounted to the wall.

For reference, I used SolidWorks 2016 to create the LED mounts.

description.text:
UPDATE 8-21-17: I added extra small hole lid. This should prevent tiny seeds such as alfalfa seeds from falling out on the first 3 rinses.

These mason jar lids are for sprouting and/or removing hulls.

Instructions:

  1. Add ~1/2 tsp - 1 tsp of alfalfa seeds
  2. Soak the seeds for ~8 hours
  3. Drain
  4. Rinse 2-4 times a day and let it sit with the lid side down.
  5. Increment to larger holes to remove bad seeds and old hulls
  6. Enjoy after 5-7 days

Recommendation:

  1. I'd recommend sprouting one jar a day for a few days. This way you can enjoy several back to back days of fresh sprouts.
  2. Experiment with several seed varieties. Start with alfalfa and mung beans and go from there.

Other:
The scad files are for reference only so if you see any problems and need changes let me know.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g97p2IY7kGM

So you got yourself into the mix with a smart home huh? wondering where to place that new Logitech elite remote? but you notice there aren't many good places to place the charging station and you don't want to lose another cup holder. well save yourself the headache and print this guy out. It saved me space for a regular size cup as you can see here and the remote is within arms reach at an angle you can glance at quickly.
when printing this mount know that you will need support and this print will take a while, do to that fact. once the mount is removed from the support know that you may wonder why the elite remote charging station feels like its not fitting loosely and that was done on purpose to allow the end user to press the elite in place in order to keep the charging station from moving. When installing the mount make sure to align the back dead center so that your micro usb can connect to the charging station. once complete you can enjoy the mount and the cup holder the way it was intended to.

title: Dino Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
VIDEO: https://youtu.be/SbAL5hIIrNI

This the very first puzzle that I ever made! Unlike all my other puzzles, this one was designed in AutoCAD (which, for the record, is terrible for designing puzzles). It was printed at my school in natural-colored PLA. The pictured sample has an interesting infill pattern that may not be replicated on your printer! I don't even know how I got the slicer to behave that way in the first place.

There are some small issues with the design - namely, the fillets are a bit too small, so the pieces need to be sanded a bit to prevent catching. Despite small issues, it's a pretty decent puzzle overall.

This core was designed to work with PLA! When printed in ABS, the holes might be slightly too large. As with most of my puzzles, it requires standard Dayan hardware for 57mm cubes, available on Lightake or Thecubicle.

PARTS ROSTER:
24x DinoCubeHalfEdgev2.stl
1x DinoCubeCorev4.stl
8x DinoCubeCornerv2(+ Base).stl
(OPTIONAL)
8x DinoCubeCornerCap.stl

author: ARGluck

print_settings.Notes:: I prefer doing a lot of sanding and filing afterwards. You may want to optimize the defaults further.

title: WW2 Aircraft Reflector Gunsight - Revi 16b - GPS HUD capable

description.text:
This is a replica Revi 16b gunsight used during WW2 by the Luftwaffe. Includes optional mount for use as a digital speedometer HUD using an inexpensive GPS unit. Never install/place this in any vehicle without first consulting with your local law enforcement (as I did).

Forward glass lever/detents, dimmer switch, and rear access hinged door all have capability for articulation as originally intended. Instructions are included.

Aircraft which used this model were:
Dornier Do 335, Focke-Wulf Fw 190 A and D, Ta 152, Heinkel He 162,
Messerschmitt Bf 109 F, G and K, Me 163 and Me 262.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

75%

Notes:

.3mf Cura file is attached which includes all of the settings used to print this model on my Anet A8.

I prefer doing a lot of sanding and filing afterwards. You may want to optimize the defaults further.

Additional Optional Hardware:

-1/4" thick plexiglass or equivalent. Model comes with printable templates for measuring and cutting.
Simply scribe the plexiglass using templates, cut with hacksaw, and file with large mill file.
Forward glass requires tinting. Had little luck with Rit dye. Any recommendations would be
great!

-#6-32 nylon pan head screws: I found these came really close and were easy on the
tapped portions.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00F3336X2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

-Optical glass lenses: I didn't order one for my project, but various sizes may be ordered on amazon for a decent price.

-Glass retainers may be used as templates to make retainers out of steel sheet.

GPS Speedometer Attachment:

GPS speedometer attachment:

-Optional mount is included for attaching an economical GPS speedometer. Gunsight dovetail will slide right in. GPS slides in below. Main gunsight body requires very careful material removal on the underside.
I was able to drill four holes on the bottom side and use a scroll saw blade by hand to make the window.
Again, never install/place anything on any vehicle without first consulting with local law enforcement and laws.

Speedometer works in dusk/night and just needs one USB 5V source. It may be found here:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LJCA1B0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Optical coating is also needed to keep the double glass effect away. Looks pretty sharp and is non-adhesive.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MXE417D/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Other remarks:

Forward glass lever will slide up and down but one must file down the faux ball catches and arms for better action. I hope to upgrade the model someday to alleviate the interference. Additional holes will need to be measured and drilled in a few areas where it would have been structurally prohibitive to include during the print.

All can be printed (as shown in image) at once on an Anet A8, but I would recommend printing parts individually for better quality prints. For reference, the main body (without attachments) should be scaled to a width of 66mm when printed/done.

I painted the main parts with a base coat of Tamiya Aluminum spray. Then painted over with Tamiya XF-1 Flat Black acrylic paint and scuffed wear & tear using scotch brite.

Design:

Modeled and dimensioned in Blender using original Revi 16b drawing.

Sliced in Cura and printed on Anet A8.

The definition of the English word "egg" ready to print on your very own egg (with an Eggbot, of course).  A great visual aid for those learning English!
The concept for this design was inspired by a similar design by Tim Docker.  And, BTW, doing this design was my impetus for writing the Spiral Text Eggbot extension for the Eggbot.  So, foreign language speakers out there: you too can render your language version of this design using that extension.

The drawing is 800 x 3200 pixels and consists of two layers:
1 - test: this is a test layer. Plot it with or without a pen to check the framing of your egg. It has two tiny, horizontal strokes at y=0 and y=800.
2 - text: this is the layer with the recipe. Plot it after you have things centered to your liking.
Use the "Layers" tab of the Eggbot Control extension to plot each layer individually.
NOTE BENE: These files wrap the text around and around the egg by using the Eggbot Control's "Egg (x) axis wraps around" option. Be sure to set that option on the "Options" tab of the Eggbot Control extension and then click the "Apply" button.
The egg shown here was drawn using a 005 Pigma Micron fibre tip technical pen.

description.text: Custom 40% keyboard plate and base. Untested
Long chain easy to print version

This is my first full design for an RC car. Everything was was completely designed by me except for 2 parts, Part 001 and 004, those gears were taken and modified from BARSPIN, (Very nice guy check him out, https://www.thingiverse.com/barspin)

As This is my first design it is a work in progress and plan to update it as I find problems.
If you have any questions I would be happy to talk to you. If you have suggestions I'd love to hear them

Also everything is design to be easily printed on a 120mm^3 build platform (because that's the size of my printer

As of right now (7/30/2017)
You will need:
1/10 scale rc motor/esc
32-pitch (0.8 mod) pinion gear
Battery (whatever you want but needs to be small)
2 8-9 gram servos
receiver/transmitter

Hardware: (not exact)
All M3 screws
16mm x60
30mm x30
40mm x20
M3 nylock nut x60

I don't have any instructions for the build, however that is yet to come.

Main Issues:
Needs shocks
Steering links need to be able to pivot more
Needs chassis supports to stop flexing
Some parts may need to be thicken for strength
Needs wheels (uses 12mm hex)
Part 001 and 002 can be one part
Here are all the parts with their recomended print settings. Some of these setting can be changed without error. If you have any questions just ask

I printed this in PLA. It requires two springs to fit over the posts. I picked these up locally. It may be necessary to heat the arms of the lid and bend them inwards slightly. Some printers tend to cause them to spread outwards, making them less likely to catch on the body and hold the press in place.

Update: I thought I should be a little more specific regarding the springs I used. While I picked them up at a local fastener store, they are made by Century Spring Corp (www.centuryspring.com). They are the C-756 utility compression spring (23/32 x 3-1/2 x 0.41 inches). Hope this helps.

print_settings.Notes:: Used 30% infill and 3 shells to ensure rigidity and support the lid structure.  There is very little infill space in general, except for the flat surface on the lid and base for only a few layers.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Dog Poop Bag Holder for smaller leash

description.text:
I remixed this from the files provided in the comments for https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2317291 designed by teamxeri.

This was modified to fit a 15mm wide lead/leash instead of the 25mm wide original version.

Additionally, I changed threading to provide a smooth screw-on lead, with additional detents on the lid to make it easier to grip; as well as rounding edges around the dogbone slot to reduce friction on the bags and softened edges all around.

title: Räsvelg Canopy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The canopy from the Räsvelg 3" and 5" race quads. This canopy has a built-in 7mm spacer and is designed to bolt to a 2-layer 30.5mm stack, and is designed specifically to hold HS1177-style cameras without mounting hardware.

Supported FPV cameras:

  • HS1177 / Foxeer XAT600M
  • RunCam Swift V1

This canopy does not fit the Foxeer Arrow, RunCam Swift 2, or RunCam Eagle as they lack the nubs requires to snap into the canopy.

Installing the camera by drilling screws through the side of the canopy will compromise the ability of the canopy to absorb impact and will likely result in broken canopies and cameras. Do it at your own risk.

Supported lenses

The canopy is designed for 14mm outer diameter lenses, with camera nub holes for 1.8mm and 2.8mm focal length lenses. Some 2.5mm lenses may fit, but only if they have an outer diameter of 14mm.

Required hardware

Depending on the thickness of the frame, you'll need some fairly long M3 screws. The 3.5mm Räsvelg 3 uses 25mm screws in the front and 30mm in the back, so you can count on requiring 22mm + plate thickness in the front, and 27mm + plate thickness in the rear.

Finally, you'll need 4 M3 locknuts and 4 5mm M3 standoffs, and perhaps some o-rings to space things out and provide a little damping.

Where to buy

Räsvelg kits are available at http://falconmultirotors.com/rasvelg.html

Professionally printed canopies are available from Phoenix 3D solutions:

  • Nylon: https://www.phx-3d.com/product-page/r%C3%A4svelg-nylon-canopy
  • TPU: https://www.phx-3d.com/product-page/r%C3%A4svelg-tpu-canopy

License

Like the sidebar says, Garuda Race Canopy is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike license.

Please refer to https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/us/ for the full details. We're not lawyers, but here are some guidelines:

  • NonCommercial —You can't sell printed canopies or make profit when printing for others as a favor. Don't put it up on your website and offer it for sale.

  • Attribution — You need to credit Falcon Multirotors when sharing your remixes. Please upload your remixes to Thingiverse with a title that makes it clear what you changed, and cite this thing under the Remixes section so others can find your awesome modifications (which covers credit and linking to the license). We also appreciate it if you link to http://falconmultirotors.com as well!

  • ShareAlike — This means you need distribute your remixes under the same license.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100

Notes:

Print in nylon preferably, or TPU otherwise.

author: rwxr

title: DE200 FIX TOP avec LED intégrées

description.text:
Amélioration des fixations hautes de la Discoeasy200 pour y intégrer des LED.

Au total il y a 6 leds orientées sur les 4 angles et le milieu du plateau, permettant un éclairage par le haut de la DE200.

Pas de câble apparent, car le courant passe par les barres structurelles verticales, qui sont conductrices, et qui ont une résistance électrique interne négligeable, donc ça ne pose pas de problèmes!

L'alimentation se fait avec du 12V DC, il est préférable de ne pas utiliser l'alimentation originale fournie par Dagoma, car elle envoie du 5A, ce qui est calculé pour la consommation de l'imprimante, pas plus.

Dans mon cas, les 6 leds consomment 33mA, et je possède une alim 12V 25A pour toutes les améliorations électriques.

TUTO:

il faudra:

  • 6 leds de 5mm de diamètre en 3.2V
  • 2 résistance de 150 Ohm
  • du câble électrique mou de 1mm
  • de quoi souder ou de la gaine thermo-rétractable

Personnellement j'ai fais la jonction entre les différents composants avec de la gaine thermo rétractable, mais il est tout à fait possible de les souder a l'étain.

à noter que deux configurations sont possible pour alimenter les leds avec les barres:

  • chaque coté peut être indépendant, deux barres reliées au + et deux barres au - .
    Cela simplifie le câblage dans les fixes, mais le complexifie dans la partie basse de l'imprimante, il faudra alors 4 câbles.
  • avoir seulement un coté relié aux polarités, mais avec les barres structurelles horizontales hautes qui font le pont pour alimenter la deuxième fixe haute.
    Cela simplifie le câblage dans la partie basse mais oblige à faire un pont électrique avec du câble entre les deux barres du + et les deux barres du - dans une des fixes.

MONTAGE:

  • choisir quelle barre recevra le + et le -
  • plier les tiges des leds à 90° afin de respecter les polarités (comme sur schéma)
  • enfoncer les leds dans leur réceptacle
  • souder les composants et 5 cm de fil électrique de chaque coté
  • dénuder 2 cm de câble aux extrémités et l'enrouler sur l'axe de la vis de serrage des barres verticales, de façon à ce que la bobine de câble se retrouve derrière l’écrou.
  • raccorder les extrémités inférieures des barres avec le +12V et la masse.

ATENTION: Après cela les barres seront sous tension, ne faite pas de cour jus avec un objet conducteur !

Bon print!!

author: ragnaroque

description.text:
Small tool to help fine-tuning bed level and axis position.

Be very careful when positioning the axis on top of the tool, use the minimal amount of jog movement when controlling the z-axis and manual positioning by hand (if allowed) to move print bed and extruder in the y-axis and z-axis to avoid collision and damage.

First use the tool to ensure the x-axis is on a parallel plane above the y-axis. Move the x-axis close to the tool. Turn the threaded rods by hand until to tool touches the x-axis on both y-axis the same way.

Next the build plate can be leveled in the same manner by adjusting the screws on the print bed. Slide the tool along the x-axis (as seen in the pictures) for different y positions of the bed to ensure the bed is parallel to the x-axis.

You can use the plane surface or the cutout of the tool for calibration as seen in the pictures. If there is an endstop near one y-axis, preventing the tool to fit with the cutout, use the plane section of the tool for the first calibration step.

title: angled and arched cam cleat riser

description.text:
for mounting the cam cleats on the arched wooden bars on our new sailing boat I hopped into sketchup and made this little riser.

[NOT YET PRINTED & TESTED]

0. photo's

first I took some photos of the underside of a cam cleat and of the profile of the wooden bar with a ruler next to it as scale

1. setting up in sketchup

I imported my photo's into sketchup
rotated them so the ruler was on an axis
and traced them with arcs

2. solids

now the extrude tool is used to make those arcs into solids

3. solid boolean function

now using the subtract tool we can subtract the wooden bar from the riser and end up with a usable object

4. print and test fit

After this step I printed it out and tested the fit.
Everything was perfect until I tried to bolt it on...

5. spotting errors

the error I made was that the holes in the bar where I had to bolt it on were not centred and thus the cam cleat was on and angle and the bolts didn't fit.

6. fixing errors

to fix my error, I bolted it on without cam cleat and measured the angle of the top surface with the compass app on my phone. 15° off. let's fix it.

that easy huh?

print_settings.Infill:: No Infill, but lots of shells

title: PTFE Tube cap with filament catch

description.text:
Part of my filament storage are PTFE tubes. But having the filament ends loosely flying around isn't ideal. On the one hand they can absorb water from the air (depending of the filament type), on the otherhand it looks a bit messy. And if the end slips into the tube you have to open the box, ...
My solution for this problem is a little cap with two conical parts. The first one catches the filament, the second one the PTFE tube.

As usual I've attached the Fusion 360 file to make adjustments easier for you. You will also find a factory file with the settings from my Prusa MKS2 and PLA from rigid ink. This time I've added lots of duplicates and processes. Each process prints one duplicate. On my Prusa I can execute all process sequential (but in one gcode file). This reduces the print time by reducing the travel time between the items. The print head does not touch the previously printed items.

Side note: I'm new to 3D printing and I've to learn everything. I believe that making things on your own from the very first step is harder but finally you will get things done. Because of that I try not to download lot of things but create them from scratch. Even if they already exists. By sharing those things I hope to get feedback that I can improve my skills. So don't be angry if I upload things which already exists here.

Update 2017.07.30: Image added

You can find my related things/parts here:

IKEA box SAMLA cover clamps: https://goo.gl/j8uJJW
IKEA box SAMLA Spool holder with mounting helper: https://goo.gl/Lesu5Q
IKEA box SAMLA Spool holder spacer: https://goo.gl/F7ovvC

author: johncantsee

description.text:
For leveling the bed on a (delta) 3D printer, you move the head to different positions near each of the three towers and then adjust a screw to make the head come out at the same height above the bed in each of the corners.

If you place this at the right spot near one of the towers, you can command the head to move to that tower, at say 35mm height, and then to come down to 23.2 (this is the height with the default settings). When all goes well, you hit the middle of the platform on the short end of the see-saw. (make sure the hotend is COLD! :-) ) and the indicator will move up. The middle of the scale is what you're aiming for.

Adjust the "go to" height at the first tower to put the stick in the middle. Then move over to the next tower and adjust the endstop to make the stick end up in the middle here as well. Continue this way on the third tower. Now your bed should be level. If necessary, you can now repeat this in the middle of the bed to see if you've calibrated your rod lengths correctly.

I use a little script called "X":

!/bin/sh

if [ $# -ge 1 ] ; then
  Z=$1
else
  Z=2
fi
echo G0 X-95 Y-55 Z$Z F6000 > /dev/ttyUSB0

(the script of course starts with #!/bin/sh, thingiverse markdown doesn't understand that I don't need a header in a code section).
to go to the X tower, optionally at a specific height. If you intend to use this script for this task, I recommend to make the default that 35 I recommended earlier.

next use a script say called "lower" to do

!/bin/sh

echo G0 Z$1 > /dev/ttyUSB0

so that you can say "lower 23.2" to go to that height.

I use these on my "octopi" control-computer for the 3D printer.

I printed this in PETG. I used a bend_len much shorter, causing the device not to bend back fully after being depressed. You might need an even longer bend_len if you print in PLA.

For printing you need to rotate it by 90 degrees. No support, I recommend a significant brim because otherwise the long bars will pull loose from the bed (maybe not necessary for PLA).

My printer is unable to resolve the tickmarks fully. However you can easily see them even if they don't look like what was designed.

When customizing: ratio is the "amplification ratio" between the head and the indicator.
Adjust bend_len for the bendy-ness of your material.
Ideally the bend_thickness is one single extrusion width. But I couldn't get my slicer to connect that piece of my model with the outside of the rest of the model. So the printer would try to extrude that short piece of material after a long move and I'd end up with three completely separate parts. Check the layers view of your slicer before printing!

I printed it at 10mm width, and I thought 5mm would be enough to hit the platform. On the other hand, the device might become too top-heavy and topple over too easily If you print it and that happens to you, let me know and I'll put the default back to 10mm.

We decided to A) print it again, and B) use it again. It was now a snap to level the bed: Just read the indicator, turn the screw and try again.

Sine and Lace is an Inkscape extension intended for use with the Eggbot.  It may be used to draw sinusoidal and lace patterns with periods a multiple of the document size.  Two curves drawn with the extension may be selected and have a third curve drawn such that it is bounded by the first two curves.  In short, the extension is intended for generating some fun patterns for drawing on eggs.

Before you can use this extension, you need to download the eggbot_sineandlace.py and eggbot_sineandlace.inx files.  Both of those files are contained in the eggbot_sineandlace.zip file which you can download from this page.  Open the zip file and place its contents in your local Inkscape extension folder,
~/.config/inkscape/extensions/
on Linux and OS X.  On Windows systems, you can place them directly in the Inkscape extension directory.  For example, if Inkscape is installed in C:/Program Files/Inkscape then the extension directory will be C:/Program Files/Inkscape/share/extensions.
Once you have placed the two files in the proper directory, exit and then restart Inkscape.  The extension should appear under the "Extensions > Eggbot Contributed" menu as "Sine and Lace...".
When using the extension there are eleven fields you can set
Width (pixels) should typically be set to the document's width in pixels.  For an Eggbot plot, that's 3200 pixels.  However, you can use whatever width you need: the curve will have that width horizontally.
Height (pixels) specifies the vertical peak to trough height of the curve.
Number of cycles (periods) controls the number of periods of the curve form to produce across the specified width.
The field "Start angle at 2 pi (n / m); n = " is used to control the starting phase (angle) of the sine or lace curve.  Values of 0 and 1 for n and m = 2 are typical when generating a curve and a version of the same curve 180 degrees out of phase.  See the green and blue touching sine waves in the lower half of the sample .svg file: the green one has n=0, m=2 and the blue one n=1, m=2.  They were started at different starting y coordinates.
The field "Start angle at 2 pi (n / m); m = " is used to control the starting phase of the sine or lace curve.  See the immediately preceding paragraph for mors details.
Recede from envelope is used to scale the amplitude of a curve being bounded by two other curves.  The amplitude will be reduced by the specified percentage.  This helps alleviate visual issues caused be imprecise pen positioning (slippage) during plotting.  For a value of 100, the curve is drawn full (100%) amplitude.  For a value of 5%, it will be drawn only 95% of it's full size; i.e., multiplied by a scaling factor of 0.95.
Number of sample points specifies how many points along the curve to sample.  In order to get good results, this value needs to be fairly high when drawing lace and the "Spline" check box is checked.
Starting x coordinate (pixels) specifies exactly that: the horizontal page position to begin the curve at.
Starting y coordinate (pixels) is the starting page vertical position to begin the curve at.  Keep in mind that with SVG and Inkscape, y=0 is at the top of the document and increasing y values move down towards the document's bottom.
To draw lace, check the "Lace" checkbox.  When unchecked, a sine wave is drawn.
To generate a sequence of splines rather than straight line segments, check the "Spline" checkbox.  When using splines and drawing lace, the number of sample points needs to be large.
To bound a curve by two previously drawn curves, select the two bounding curves and then select Extensions > Eggbot Contributed > Sine and Lace....  You cannot use a curve which itself was bound by two other curves.

This is a remix of the turtle head of "Squishy Turtle" by jakejake. You will need to download the other parts of this turtle from the original design (see link at the left)

I have a small child who loves to play with these turtles, but he removes its head all the time and it always gets lost. Because of this, I created a remix of the turtle head that can't be removed after the turtle is assembled, but it's still possible to hide it in the shell as the original design.

description.text:
As with all the designs I put on here, let me know what you think in the comments.

I needed a GoPro Strap Clip to fit on the elasticated sections of the shoulder straps on my Lowepro Viewpoint BP 250 AW backpack, I the one that would fit on here but noticed after printing it didn't perfectly fit my GoPro Hero Plus, the gaps between the mounting point fingers are exactly the same as the GoPro mount fingers size, which made it very hard to mount the GoPro.

I will mention the previous design is a genius move though, just needed some cleaning.

In my remixed version the sizes are corrected to allow easier mounting of the GoPro as well as cleaning up some of the edges and also adding an indent into the sides of the mount where the threaded but pushes through (the previous holes due to the miss sized mount are to think, so the standard GoPro bolt wasn't long enough)

I have also added a small amount of my own design flare to just clean things up a little for printing.

If you have any suggestions for future changes feel free to comment.

title: Stacking Planter Pods, a new concept in vertical, nesting herb and flower gardens - UPDATED to Version 2

description.text:
UPDATED to Version 2:

What's new: Drainage-holes have been added to all planter pods, draining into the center-hole. The center-hole has new vertical drainage-channels which allow the pods to drain even if you place a rod down the center of the planter. The pods have a raised and angled floor designed to promote drainage. I would recommend placing a small amount of coffee filter or something like that to keep soil from draining out.

More than two years in the making, I can finally reveal my original concept for a stacking, nesting modular herb-garden planter!

After the success of my self-watering planter design, I began thinking about a way to build this kind of vertical stacking planter. Inspired by the structure of a pinecone, I expect this to be the first in a series of stackables in the same vein.

At the time, my CAD skills were not up to the task of creating this, and I struggled with how to generate the perfectly-nesting curves required for this concept to work. But now I have that figured out at last after working on other problems, and was able to successfully produce this excellent design.

I hope you are as excited about this idea as I am; I can easily see people building herb-gardens in their kitchen windows, mounting these on lazy-susans that let them rotate the whole garden and choose which herbs get the most sun, or even take advantage of the center-hole to mount them on a pole or hang them from the roof.

These nesting herb pods let you grow any number of garden herbs or flowers, and mix or match them as desired.

The size is roughly 7.5" diameter, which is probably a bit larger than it needs to be. Let me know if you guys are interested in a smaller or larger design. The individual pods aren't much more than 4" in any one direction, and should be printable by most 3D printers. As for the height, it's only limited by how many you want to print, though very tall versions should consider using a stick or wire-rope down the center to keep it from toppling over. I would not be surprised if it turns out to be very stable though.

The slot-and-tongues used to hold the pods together have fairly loose tolerances, about .020" extra space overall, so that even if your printer isn't great at holding good tolerances it should work decently fine. They may prove to be too loose in fact; if so let me know. You can always stuff those holes with a bit of toilet-paper if they prove too lose, to tighten them up again.

Another feature is a .190" hole in the back through to the center-hole, this is designed to accept a short #10 screw, the idea being that you can insert a wooden-rod or plastic dowel down the half-inch hole either for extra support to hold it all together or to mount it in some unusual spot rather than placing it on a table or something.

It might also be possible to run water-tubes in through these holes and rig-up some kind of automatic watering drip system. I can produce a version with a larger center-hole if anyone feels the need.

And, as always, my designs are completely open-source, public-domain dedicated. Feel free to alter in any way you like, even to commercialize them immediately. In fact, if I don't see these for sale in Home Depot by the end of the year, I will be disappointed :P

Some additional thoughts:

  • The wall-thickness modeled is .100".

  • The walls need to be water tight. It may help to use some secondary process to make the pods water-tight if your print fails to produce a water-tight product. Hot-wax perhaps? Or pitch?

  • In the images of the assembly, I've colored one of the pods blue so it is easy to see how an individual pod is part of the larger whole.

  • The footer parts and the top parts were made from the same stacking-pod model as the pods themselves, modified for that position. They are optional to use. So the entire assembly is constructed from three-separate model variants of one pod.

  • It could be made into a hanging-planter by passing a wire or string through the center of a piece of wood dowel and tying off a knot, then screwing each pod into the dowel with a short #10 screw from the inside of the pod (about .500" length or so should be enough).

title: D-Bot Chimera/Cyclops adapter for the Dual Nimble using the printingSome carriage

description.text:
It has come to my attention that this adapter will not fit the original carriage plates. What I thought to be the original plates were actually these plates: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2206664

The adapters for the original plates are coming along and I will post a link here when they are done.

Straight forward mount for a Chimera or Cyclops. The Dual Nimble bolts to the heat sink though the adapter and clamps it all together. Really simple and easy to make adapter.
It leaves enough space for sensors and fan mounts.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

title: Diamond Nozzle mount for 3 Nimbles with 50 mm ball centers

description.text:
An effector for the Diamond nozzle or hot end.
This is not an easy shape and I expect it will be difficult to print and assemble.

I tried to make the Nimbles face roughly the same way, so you do not have to walk around the printer to open the breeches when changing filaments.
The whole thing, from the top of the fan to the tip of the nozzle is 115.5 mm tall. It is designed to use Haydns magnetic joints with a ball spacing of 50 mm. I tried to squeeze it into 43 mm but it is a VERY tight package. If a lot of people want it, I will try and make it work.
Edit: Updated the cooling shroud. Thickened to bottom layer, it was too thin to print via Shapeways. I have also added a Shapeways model, so it can be ordered directly from there. http://shpws.me/OQhm
Edit2: First indications are that for a Delta, this doesn't work. The width is to much and interferes with the arms.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

author: compi_hu

description.text: Let's face it, alot ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17381 ) of the headphone clips on here are complicated. Who needs to take 5 minutes to wind your headphones into some contraption (my own confusing headphone contraption from a year ago included). So, I made this little clip to hold everything together.

Wind your headphones round your fingers, then jam them into the slot on this clip. Give them a 1/4 twist to hold them in.
I made this out of PLA with .15mm layer height. With a solid fill, it's almost as translucent as the feedstock.

description.text:

Updates
30.07.2017 - 13:55: Initial Upload
V3.1 doesn't break as easily when putting on the case and the finger print reader should be in the right spot now.
-Will not reprint it though.

How to print it:
Change the text to whatever you like (0,5mm hight) and put some rounding on it (picture above) so it feels better.
Print it with the text faceing upwards.

How to put it on:
Put the phone into the side with the volume buttons. Now it is possible to press the phone in from the bottom left corner on the other side.
BE CAREFUL! YOUR PHONE MIGHT GET SCRATCHED BY PUTTING ON THE CASE.
If you don't want to risk your phone getting scratched or the case eventually breaking in the top left corner (or the whole case), redesign the case and make the overhang on the case smaller.

Material I used: PLA

Printed with an unmodded Prusa i3 clone.
All dimensions in millimeters.

title: Pegboard Air (or any 66.5mm)  Can Holder!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Okay so you working at the bench and you need a little shot of compressed air so you go off and waste time searching for that can of compressed air that seems to be where you think it is. Did the wife take it, or maybe the kids to dry off the dog? Well what if I told you there was an answer to this problem, what would you be willing to pay? Well there is and here it is for free! Yes free as all you need is a 3D printer and some filament and your off to the races! As the backing of this matches stock peg board spacing and therefore you can use real metal hooks (like these: http://amzn.to/2eXZd3U) to attach it to the pegboard (3d printed plastic ones tended to break too often) so found this to be a practical solution! Wait, what your out of compressed air cans? How can that be, well just click here http://amzn.to/2uNMuEy as these are ones I use!

Note: this will also work for basically any 66.5mm or there about diameter can.

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Any 200mm x 200mm printer will work

No

Yes

.3 or better you pick

15% or so...

You need to print support everywhere as the circle opening will give you issues and just use a clean up tool like this http://amzn.to/2hdzLbp to make it nice and smooth! Wait you don't have one of these (http://amzn.to/2hdzLbp) clean up tools yet? Well its time for you to come into the 21st centry and get one! (click here: http://amzn.to/2hdzLbp and you can thank me later). as this is one handy print! Oh wait you out of compressed air cans? Well just just click here: http://amzn.to/2uNMuEy as this is the cans I use and modeled this around!

description.text:
the motor mounts had a issue of being flexible.,.. so i fixed that issue...
if any other issues come to pass with hararis lead screw upgrade i will re do the parts and upload them.. also use super glue get your self some good super glue not the cheap kind thin so it flows and coat the layers this seals it if you use pla also abs you can use super glue why again seals and it prevents layer separation.. you can get away with just sealing the x axis as that holds weight the upper mounts you dont need to do this too .. the lower motor mounts i would..
also youll see black come off this is normal.. ca glue is compatible dont worry... it works great you can also sand the part which i plan to do to mine give 48 hours for total cure dont use acelaorators they leave a white milky residue and weaken it...
you may not sell or distribute this.. or sell on ebay... you may remix it as you see fit... its 3 times as strong so no need to do anything to it now fits perfectly with the settings i specified.. you also do not need to fix i already did that before hand.. tolerances 0.020

again parts remade.. not to resell.. only for personal use.. you may remix them as you see fit..

author: domijo59

description.text:
Part of my filament storage are PTFE tubes. If I don't use the filament 4 tubes per container are loosely hanging around. That's not handy. So I've created this little organizer to get rid of them. I glued two of the clamps to one side of a container and clamp the tubes by using the natural twist of the filament to the side. Everything is easy and manageable.

As usual I've attached the Fusion 360 file to make adjustments easier for you. You will also find a factory file with the settings from my Prusa MKS2 and PLA from rigid ink. This time I've added some duplicates and processes. Each process prints one duplicate. On my Prusa I can execute all process sequential (but in one gcode file). This reduces the print time by reducing the travel time between the items. The print head does not touch the previously printed items.

Side note: I'm new to 3D printing and I've to learn everything. I believe that making things on your own from the very first step is harder but finally you will get things done. Because of that I try not to download lot of things but create them from scratch. Even if they already exists. By sharing those things I hope to get feedback that I can improve my skills. So don't be angry if I upload things which already exists here.

You can find my related things/parts here:

IKEA box SAMLA cover clamps: https://goo.gl/j8uJJW
IKEA box SAMLA Spool holder with mounting helper: https://goo.gl/Lesu5Q
IKEA box SAMLA Spool holder spacer: https://goo.gl/F7ovvC
PTFE tube caps with filament catch: https://goo.gl/3aACiP
PTFE tube organizer: https://goo.gl/y79yYS

The hole for the GPS mount is 4mm, it can be easily altered with Fusion360 or drilled if you need it larger.

Happy Flying!

author: cipis

title: Banggood Raspberry Pi Anet A6 camera mount

description.text: This is a Raspberry Pi backplate and Banggood camera mount (https://www.banggood.com/Camera-Module-For-Raspberry-Pi-3-Model-B-2B-B-A-p-1051437.html?rmmds=search)

Installation
  • Mount the backplate instead of the current acrylic backplate. Make sure the screws to mount the Pi are already in it and facing towards the back
  • Mount the camera using 2 or 4 M2 screws (I used the spare M2 screws of my Anet a6)
  • Mount the camera part to the extension with an M3 screw and nut (I used the spare long M3 screws and nuts)
  • Mount your raspberry pi to the backplate and use nuts to secure it in place. The reason why you have to mount the pi AFTER mounting the backplate is because the nut of the upper left screw of the backplate has to be UNDER the Pi.

NOTE 1: You may need to sandpaper the connection points a bit. They are already smaller to fit, but depending on print settings it might still be too tight.
NOTE 2: I only used spare screws and nuts to mount the Pi. The camera is mounted using 2 leftover self tapping M2 screws

title: IKEA Box SAMLA Spool holder spacer

description.text:
My spool holder serves up to 4 filament spools on an DN50 (sewage?) pipe. To separate the spools a bit and to lower the chance that one spool turns the next spool I've created this spacer.

As usual I've attached the Fusion 360 file to make adjustments easier for you. You will also find a factory file with the settings from my Prusa MKS2 and PLA from Das Filament.

Side note: I'm new to 3D printing and I've to learn everything. I believe that making things on your own from the very first step is harder but finally you will get things done. Because of that I try not to download lot of things but create them from scratch. Even if they already exists. By sharing those things I hope to get feedback that I can improve my skills. So don't be angry if I upload things which already exists here.

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Dungeon corridor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    Changelog
    =========
  • 9/01/2014 - fixed mesh problems with 1x2, 1x3, 1x4, 3x2, 3x3, 3x4, 4x2, 4x3, 4x4
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Painting

Painting was done in 4 layers.
  • Paint whole piece in black
  • Heavily dry brush with a dark grey
  • pick at least one other color (that could be stone) and paint some random stones, front and back.
  • dry brush with grey mixed with a little olive
  • lightly dry brush with a light grey, focusing most heavily on edges

FFF/FDM printers can do small 90 degrees (completely horizontal) overhangs which could be handy for adding details to your model. This is a quick test piece designers can use to get a feel of the sizing of those details.

title: HTD 3M Pulleys for Stepper and CNC

description.text: Two 32 teeth pulleys for 12mm HTD 3M (3mm) timing belt. The pulleys has the hard to find HTD profile and have god grib with timing belt. One pulley is for the stepper motor 8mm shaft and the other pulley is for the 10mm key indexed mill shaft. The pulleys is used for driving the Y axis on my Opti BF20 mill (Grizzly G0704).

Print in ABS or similair. 4-5 solid layers, 3 perimeters and 50% infill to prevent deformation. 1) Print the two pulleys. 2) To fit the 8mm stepper pulley use a sharp 8mm drill or reamer. 3) Use two M3 12mm screws and nuts for shaft mounting. 4) Surface can optionally be smoothed with acetone. Fits standard HTD 3M 12 mm timing belt. I found some low prised belts on eBay used in E-Scooter (3M-384-12, search for Drive Belt 3m 12). I can upload the STEP files on request (Parts created in Autocad Inventor).

description.text: A friend gave me some 6 x 9.7 mm magnets, I made an easy to grip housing for the magnets for a family member. The hole for the magnet is slightly small, so I used the drill press and an "A" size (0.235") bit to make the hole right. Then use a vise to push the magnet in. Works very well. Here is a tip, make sure the magnet does not go in too far, ideally it should stick out very, very slightly, If it is pushed in even a little bit too far, it loses much of its holding power.

print_settings.Notes:: The shells are only 3mm thick and don't really have enough surface contact to ensure positive adhesion. Unless you have your printer calibrated in such a way that it can handle narrow tolerances like this, I would recommend doing a raft or brim.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I found an amazing e-drum project by RyoKosaka.

His project calls for the shell to be made of a 3-layer paper stock. I got the dimensions from him and designed a 3D printed shell to add to his project as an alternative to the paper stock.

A common bed size in most consumer desktop printers is 200mm x 200mm and, unfortunately, the shell is just a hair larger than that (201.5mm major diameter). My solution to this was to quarter the shell, which allowed me to reduce the 2D footprint by half along the X- and Y-axis. Each leaf of the shell fits into a rabbet/groove combo on the bottom rim while a a groove on the top rim pushes the mesh head down and over the shell. I designed the shell in a way that all 4 pieces could be printed at the same time and so that when the top rim is tightened down, it binds each of the shell quarters to each other without causing an overlap. The added benefit of it being modeled in a CAD is that it can be modified/customized for any need or desire, should anyone choose to.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

The shells are only 3mm thick and don't really have enough surface contact to ensure positive adhesion. Unless you have your printer calibrated in such a way that it can handle narrow tolerances like this, I would recommend doing a raft or brim.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed at 50mm/s speed with 100% infill to check how much print time and filament would be required if using a borrowed printer (makerspace / library / school / friend).  The jig took a little over an hour and used under 6m of filament.  If you need to print one on a borrowed machine in order to build your own printer then you should be OK for time / material restrictions.

description.text:
Aligning extrusions seems to be the hardest part of building a frame kit. This jig simplifies getting cube corners right.
Step 1 - slide the "through" bar down the longer ribs
Step 2 - drop the other two sides onto the jig.
Step 3 - bolt the two sides into the upright (make sure the bars fit tightly against each other when you tighten them up)
Step 4 - remove the jig. It will slide off quite easily
Step 5 - bolt the remaining corner (make sure it fits tightly).

No fussing checking that faces are flush and that the bars haven't twisted.

I've also been looking at a model for printed corner brackets that I hope to share soon.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed at 50mm/s speed with 100% infill to check how much print time and filament would be required if using a borrowed printer (makerspace / library / school / friend). The jig took a little over an hour and used under 6m of filament. If you need to print one on a borrowed machine in order to build your own printer then you should be OK for time / material restrictions.

I used OpenScad with Manuel García's 2020 extrusion model as a check
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:136430
It isn't needed to make the model render.

I've included my scad file if you want to adjust for a different extrusion size.
prof is the profile width (only square section covered)
ribW is the width of the fixing rib (make it a little narrower than the extrusion's slot)
ribD is the height of the fixing rib
tolerance is a clearance value for the fins that keep the side bars snug

HyperCube CNC YouTube Playlist

Pen Holder

  • Attach a pen with a diameter between 8mm to 11mm.
  • Requires 6 x M3 hex nuts, 1 x M3x20mm screw.

1-Axis Pen Holder

  • Attach a pen with a diameter between 8mm to 11mm.
  • Requires 6 x M3 hex nuts, 1 x M3x20mm screw.
  • 1 small rubber band
  • 2 x 55mmx8mm smooth rod
  • 2 x LM8UU Linear Bearings

Laser Mount

  • Requires 4 x M3 hex nuts, 3 x M3x10mm screws.
  • 2.5w Laser
  • Safety Glasses

Drill Mount
(coming soon)

MPX 6 Connector mount and cover

  • MPX 6 Connectors

title: Oshkosh HMETT Scale Body for Axial SCX10

description.text:
Here is a scale body for an Axial SCX10. Its an Oshkosh Hmett 4x4 body. Some Supports are required depending on how they are printed. This isnt a straight print and place design yet. Some parts you may have to mess with to put in place. Some parts are glued, some are screwed (hehe, that rhymes). Anyways, so enjoy and I will do my best to answer any questions. If you would like to modify the model and use designspark mechanical, PM me and I can send you the .rsdoc files instead of converting them from an STL to a solid and dealing with the mesh. Your comments and ideas would appreciated. I will post more pictures and build updates when I get to them.

Update 8/1/2017: Sorry guys, totally forgot to upload doors. There up. Doors are designed just slightly bigger than door jam so they just pop right in. Also, Engine cab has been cut in two for smaller print Beds. Next update should include the fifth wheel hitch.

Update 8/10/17: Added Designspark Mechanical format for anyone who wants to modify the design easier.
