description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jTXt7plGUWf

The first garden sign is blank to allow for your own text. There is a indentation near the top of the sign that will hold a 3/4" label (I like to use a 3/4" P-Touch yellow label). The idea behind this was to print generic text below the slot like CORN, BEANS, CARROTS, etc. and the label slot will allow you to have more defined text like Blue CORN, Peaches and Cream CORN, etc.

This way you will only need a handful of signs printed up and if you plant something different the next year, you can reuse the sign just change the label out. The second sign has the text on it to show what it can look like.

author: AustinSaintAubin

description.text:
Both tests take less than 1 minute! There are 9 dots total and each dot indicates how level an area of the bed is. Dots that peel off, don't print, or fill in too thin indicate the bed is too low in that region. Squished dots indicate the bed is too high.

Find me on:

I was tired of trying to level by eye or using tests that take a few minutes. I decide that using small dots in targeted regions would be the most efficient way to level my beds. I leveled my Ender 2 and my Maker Select once and haven't had to re-level them. Each printer only took a few minutes.
Mounts a standard desktop HDD on the back of an optical drive.  Great for caseless computers.

You can see the configs I used to print this from Cura on the photos.

This is a pedal stopper gear part for G25/G27/G29.
Print this with 100% infill.

Added: 3D print-easy gear
This version is more easy to print.
It contains un-removable support material.
40% or higher infill is recommended :)

A somewhat more elegant and unobtrusive Z-endstop for Flyingbear P902.
...that also minimizes vibration and squeaking from the Z screw rod.

Use supports. There should only be one, and it will be trivial to pop out of the hole.
Layer height irrelevant, I used 0.2mm, PLA.

Two of the standard screws are replaced with longer ones for this (M3x16mm through the printer Z frame and this printed mount), and two (M3x20mm through the printed mount and the endstop switch) are added.
Also one M3 30-40mm for the adjustable probe part.
Two of the usual M4x8mm for the t-nuts into the 2020 frame.

You need a spring in the probe. In the photos I have just slapped in two nuts until I receive the various springs i have on order.

Installing it is a bit of a pain. Remove the Z nema and it's rod connector, unscrew the brass drive ring from the hotbed frame. Slip the printed mount block onto the screw rod and put the nema/rod roughly in position while you screw the two original bolts back into the brass drive ring on the outside edge of the printer. The rest of the reassembly will be fairly self-apparent.

I use a gcode pause to insert the nut that is inside the 'probe' section.

Naturally the moment I refined this to something I was happy with I decided to use a bltouch endstop instead. So while I have printed and installed the parts, it may never get used.

2017-09-17
Turns out there's a reason leadscrew rods are not restrained at their top end, I may be making something worse with these mounts. Although I usually drill out the rod component a little, so that the leadscrew can touch it's inside radius, but not actually be tightly constrained by the entire inner circumference of the mount... so YMMV
https://www.evernote.com/shard/s211/sh/701c36c4-ddd5-4669-a482-953d8924c71d/1ef992988295487c98c268dcdd2d687e
"In these designs, when the rod is only constrained at one end, if the rod is not perfectly straight (which none are), the free end will move in small circles the way the CupcakeCNC's platform did, but the Z axis will not be affected because the smooth rods constrain it to a linear path, and the shaft couplers allow a bit of flex when the Z nuts push the rod in one direction or another. Some less experienced users were confused or concerned by the wobble exhibited by the free ends of these rods and decided to put bearings on them to prevent this wobble."

title: Radial Ran Fang - E3D Cyclops and Chimera Editions

description.text:
Remixes for the Radial Fan Fang for the E3D Chimera dual extruder and Cyclops.

High infill recommended, particularly on the "sensor editions," or the mounts will be weak.

NOTE: The famed "Ball of air" effect is less effective for the Chimera than for the Cyclops. It is not possible to create a dual focal point for the Chimera with only 2 fan ducts.

It has been pointed out that the fan ducts seem to be about 1 mm further back than ideal. This is an intentional change. I did this because the mounting screw holes tend to be relatively weak and break easily no matter how I print them. I have found that putting a small (1mm thick) washer on both sides of the mount hole spreads out the pressure enough that the holes do not break as easily if you accidentally overtighten the screw. It also holds the mount in place more securely.So i put one washer on the screw, feed it through the mount hole, add another washer, then screw it into the heatsink.

Update: Resolved Simplify3d issue with mesh, and added a hole in BLTouch mount to allow wires to pass through

Update: Fixed non-manifold sections of models that were making the sensor and fan mounts weak

First Chimera versions

Optimized polygon count. The "thingiview" and preview images look "chunky," but the finished print is almost indistinguishable from the original

Measurements corrected for Cyclops

Raised BLTouch mount by 3 mm

Last Chimera models added.

BLTouch mount moved on Chimera models to better clear the duct

Update: Fixed self-intersections on some models that were causing weak areas or holes when being printed.

Update: Still some issues with self-intersections in Simplify3D, making some parts weak. Slic3r seems to be able to auto-correct them. Slic3r recommended for printing until I can fix the Simplify3d issues.

Update: Finally! Simplify3d issues have been resolved. Models should work with any slicer now. Thank you https://makeprintable.com for your assistance in resolving the issues with the original STL's. Apologies for the previous inconvenience.

Please let me know if you discover any problems and I will look into them

print_settings.Notes:: These print fine at 0.3 mm layer height, but many printers have a 0.04 mm z height stepper motor resolution, so it looks MUCH better when you print these at 0.28 mm height.  The printer can do 0.3 mm layer, but it is holding the z axis between stepper points, so you will get some wobbly action in the z axis.  0.28 mm has no wobble so layer adhesion is MUCH better and it looks MUCH better.  You should try to have your layer height a multiple of 0.04 mm.

title: Firefly: The Game card deck holders

description.text:
I looked at a lot of card deck holders for Firefly. I really liked davidandmaraya's best (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1924234), but I wanted to make some improvements. So I created these models that print in 1/2 the time and are much more compact.

These models are optimized for printers with a 0.4 mm nozzle and 2 perimeter shells. Infill doesn't need to be more than 20% and supports are NOT required.

UPDATE 8/28/2017 The Supply deck would occasionally tip over backwards on me, so I increased the angle of back supports by 5 degrees.

UPDATE 8/29/2017 I added models for sleeved cards that will accommodate all the expansions.

NOTE: The contact and supply deck holders will accommodate 10mm of cards (starter game plus Breakin' Atmo). Some expansions add additional cards. The Burn deck will accommodate 14mm of cards which covers the Alliance Space, Border Space, and Aim to Misbehave decks (starter game plus Breakin' Atmo). You can use the Burn deck holders if you have more than 10mm thick deck of supply cards. Otherwise, please let me know how thick your deck is and I can create a custom holder for your cards. My models are parametric so it is super easy to create additional versions.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.28mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These print fine at 0.3 mm layer height, but many printers have a 0.04 mm z height stepper motor resolution, so it looks MUCH better when you print these at 0.28 mm height. The printer can do 0.3 mm layer, but it is holding the z axis between stepper points, so you will get some wobbly action in the z axis. 0.28 mm has no wobble so layer adhesion is MUCH better and it looks MUCH better. You should try to have your layer height a multiple of 0.04 mm.

title: BLTouch mount for Nova Labs BG printers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
BLTouch mount for Nova Labs BG printers. It is definitely compatible with BG8 printer, and likely works BG6, BG7, BGIX and BGX as well.

It is a bolt-in replacement for the existing capacitive sensor. Mount using some M3 screws through the BL Touch, add two M3 washers (gross height adjustment), through the mount, then add a nut.

Fine adjustment is done via the M851 command or via the LCD: Control -> Motion -> Z Offset. Save to EEPROM when happy.

Also included is the same mount sized for an E3Dv5, which is a little taller than the E3Dv6.

A more complete write-up is here:

https://github.com/twstdpear/nl_i3_parts/tree/master/bltouch

title: Pegboard and Holes Utility!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
OK so what is this you ask, well you know how they say necessity is the mother of all invention? Well this was born from my need to have the ability to create small sections of pegboard and/or holes to draft into other projects. Now you can use this stand alone to create [a small] sheet of pegboard but more so it is intended to integrate into other projects. The best way to explain this by example, as take a look at this project https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2459524 as we used a section of pegboard created from this code to create the mounting back for this.

In addition the peg only setting is intended to create a set of pegs without a board so you can import the resulting STL again into another application such Tinkercad to either create a set of uniformed pegs or punch out holes.

Update: to get customizer to work you need to "toggle" the logic and you can do this by swtiching the "type" to pegs (0) and then back to board (1) and it will then show the board with holes :-)

See more about this code here in this Youtube video (https://youtu.be/EI0rZ7c2ve0) as well as visit our Open-SCAD website here for more resources!

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

This is experimental high gain dish antenna which i maked for NodeMcu long range. I didnt printed it because i gived up on project, but im uploading it if anyone want to print it. I maked it 100% printable, altrough you probably should file up little bit of middle section for better fitting of NodeMcu. Its maked for original NodeMcu, altrough it will probably fit with chinesse clones.

You should print like this:
Dish part x8
Mounting plate x1
Middle dish part x1
Nodemcu holder and reciever antenna x1

Whole antenna is 263mm in diameter, but separate parts will fit 20x20 printbed. I managed to pack everything at once, altrough you should print parts separately, because of nozzle cloggings and stuff... For Dish part use skirt because it have really small printing surface. You should also use ABS if you plan to put it outside because ABS is better than PLA when it comes to sun heat.
-When you print dish, glue aluminium foil from inside to reflect wifi signal toward antenna.
-On NODEMCU small printed antenna put piece of wire around 50cm long and wrap it around long part of holder.

Use zipties, glue and tape as much as your instict tell you to. When you print it, send me some pictures, because i would really like to see it how it looks when its printed.

Happy printing and hacking!

title: Anet A6 E3D Titan Extruder Carriage Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I wanted a direct drive light weight carriage for the Anet A6 which took advantage of the E3D titan extruder, with it's light weight and ability to print flexible filaments. This uses the smaller and lighter pancake motor. I designed this in Fusion 360. There are mounts for a either a Tronxy blue cube inductive sensor or the Bltouch. This mount also integrates The E3d V6 Hot end- it uses the 20 mm fan that is used in the E3d v6 fan mount. The Fan mount is integrated into the carriage design. This carriage mount uses the existing part cooling fan from your Anet A6 and there is also a nozzle included in this design that attaches to the part cooling fan duct and is screwed onto the bottom of the carriage. The Titan extruder Bracket that mounts the motor to the carriage is also custom for this setup. This carriage design represents weeks of work and prototyping. Various iterations have been printed and tried on my Anet A6. This is the final design which has been fine tuned to be quite awesome!

I used Igus bearings at the rear slide and the original steel ball linear bearing for the front. This combination gives the best accuracy and no binding. The Motor bracket is attached to the carriage using 6-6x3/8 sheet metal screws. The holes required for the screws are already designed into the carriage. I also provided holes for set screws to attach the bearings but I found that they were not neccesary, The bearings are a nice press fit. There are also screw holes provided for the E3D v6 cooling fan . Those require a #4x1/2" sheet metal screws. I provided 4 holes but only 2 diagonal holes are required to attach the 20mm fan.
The carriage needs to be printed laying on its right side with some supports. This is the way that requires the least bit of support.
The nozzle is a bit tricky to print and really should be printed with no supports unless you have a slicer that lets you customize supports. A bit of trimming with a knife, on the screw perches is required because they are recessed in to allow for 2-4x1/2" sheet metal screws to attach it. There are also screw holes designed into the carriage to attach the nozzle.

My Recommendations are to buy a Genuine E3D Titan Extruder Body and a Genuine BLtouch sensor for the best hassle free performaance. I tried the clones and they suck The Titan clone would not even turn with a pancake motor because of gear binding from out-of round gears. The clone Bltouch that I first receiverd from TriangleLabs on AliExpress was also a piece of sh&t. It didn't work at all- The light lit up but that was it...no pin movement.
If you're gonna buy a titan clone extruder at least get the one with the steel drive gear and only buy the body.At least this way, if it doesn't work out, you won't be out a ton of money, like i was. DON"T EVEN BUY A CLONE BLTOUCH>>>THEY SUCK!!!! Even the ones that work are not very accurate. The Genuine BLTOUCH is acurate to within .02mm on my machine.

As far as the E3d v6 hot end, I'm using a clone and it seems to be working fine but I didn't buy from china. I bought it from a USA seller on Ebay and it came with the fan, heat block , nozzle, throat, thermister and heater for roughly $35. It is nice!

Setting up all the firmware parameters is beyond the scope of this offering. I installed skynet 2.3.2 fix2 and that's what I've been using. There's a newer version out but i couldn't tell you what the difference is. I can attach my Configuration H file here but just be aware that a lot of the stuff is specific to my machine and may not work on yours. Use my config h as a guide only. Don't be lazy, learn your firmware!

https://youtu.be/0YpqX9-I3QU?list=PLOHlc-vGrVqyyWmqchasarLhZ6EaKnnBA

https://youtu.be/Y5UB5zVZEiA

https://youtu.be/vwDuYrNzXJk

I designed this simple and light frame for easy setup and nice looking purposes.
You have 2 designs available: One size for 3" prop and one size for 5" so that you can easily move from one size to another. Each arm weights 6gr (for 3" prop) or 8gr (for 5" prp). The rigidy of the whole concept is done by the PCB on wich the arms are fixed. This makes a very light, strong and light quadcopter. Be careful not to do races with it, it may break the PCB during a crash. Please make sure you are using 40mm x 40mm PCB because the arms are designed to fit on this kind of size.
Setup can change according to you preferences, but you must take 4in1 speed controller on 40x40mm board, one 40x40mm FC and 4x 1306 motors.

More pictures to come

AUW without battery is 147gr

title: Replacement pins for Siedle (SSS) Intercom system HT-351-0 B
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement pins for the old intercom system mady by Siedle (SSS). Name of the System: HT-351-0 B.
This system is over 35 years old now, and the pins are very often already broken.

Mounting

You need to glue the new replacement pins onto the socket of the old pins. It is possible, that you need to shorten the old pins, so the new part can fit. This can be done with a sharp knife. But be aware, that the old plastic can be very brittle!

description.text:
Mon anglais est déplorable, alors plutôt que d'infliger une torture linguistique à nos amis anglophones, je m'exprimerai en français. Mille excuses.

Profitant d'une promo sur Banggood pour cet article : DPS5015 (https://www.banggood.com/DP50V15A-DPS5015-Programmable-Supply-Power-Module-With-Integrated-Voltmeter-Ammeter-Color-Display-p-1072236.html?rmmds=search)
J'en ai pris trois et me suis lancé dans la réalisation d'une alim triple.
Certes, elle ne pourra pas délivrer 3 x 15A max mais elle me rendra bien des services. C'est sûr ;o).
Toutes les pièces ont été réalisées en PLA sauf les pieds en FLEX - en PI-ETPU 95-250 CARBON BLACK pour être exact (https://www.creativetools.se/hardware/3d-printers-and-accessories/filaments/flexible-filaments/pi-etpu-95-250-carbon-black).

150µ

25%

PLA 194°C, Bed 60°C

Fond, capot et flancs ont été imprimés à la vertical. Mon imprimante ne me permettait d'imprimer à plat, la surface du plateau étant insuffisante.

Toutes les fixations vissées ont été réalisées avec des inserts laiton M3.
L'insert se pose facilement à chaud en le plaçant sur la pointe fine d'un fer à souder (150°C) et en l'introduisant doucement dans le trou.

comme fait remarquer NKA, il y a un loup dans le dimensionnement alim générale ( 220V ac / 48V dc) vs modules alims BT.
Tout le monde ne maîtrise pas l’électronique, donc un petit tuto pour bien faire son choix des différents modules serait bienvenu
Ce sont des modules buck donc abaisseurs de tension et non des modules boost augmenteurs de tension, donc faire du 53V en sortie avec du 48V en entrée ...
As tu mesuré la vraie tension d’entrée de ton module à ce moment là ?
Vu l’heure j’espère ne pas dire de bêtise en conseillant aux novices de choisir l’alim d’entrée de la façon suivante
-1, en fonction de la tension Max que je veux en sortie sachant que tension de sortie = 1.1 x tension d’entrée
Sachant que je peux faire, comme c’est le cas de certaines alims de labo, une sortie tension Max 50V une autre 30V et une autre 12V
Je prends la tension de sortie la plus élevée ( qui peut le plus ...) donc dans cet exemple 50V et multiplie par 1.1 soit 55V de tension nécessaire en entrée des trois modules

title: Capped Y-Corners for Prusa i3 - fully parametrized

description.text:
I have two nice 9mm smooth rods salvaged from old Epson printers and I would like to use them for my new boxed-frame Prusa i3 (using my DIY brass nut bushings). So I was searching for suitable Y-corners. Instead of the zip-tied originals, I prefer the capped type, like the one published by ch1t0. But unfortunately, those are only provided as STL files, so they are not easily reconfigurable. Also, when looking at this and various other versions of Y-corners, I found that, while the rod diameters are usually given, it is not so easy to get to know the distances between the rods and there height above ground. But these parameters are equally important to have the corners fit with the accessories (e.g. y-stepper mount) and the specific frame construction. So when finally ended up writing my own SCAD code for the y-corners, I chose the main parameters to be the diameters and the center heights above ground for each of the four rods. As an additional parameter, the diameters of the corresponding washers cut-outs can also be specified. All these parameters are specified as arrays with 4 elements, corresponding to the rods from the lowest to the topmost. The caps are mounted onto the base corners by means of two M3x12mm screws and the corresponding screw nuts. STL files are provided for the following rod configurations:
  • 8mm smooth, 10mm long threaded and 8mm short threaded, at heights 10/20/30/45mm (this corresponds to the standard Prusa i3 corners)
  • 9mm smooth, 10mm long threaded and 8mm short threaded, at heights 10/20/30/45mm
  • 10mm smooth, 10mm long threaded and 8mm short threaded, at heights 10/20/30/45mm
  • all rods 10mm, at heights 14/25/36/50mm
    • Each of the above configurations STL files for 1 and for 4 corners are provided. The file names contain the rod diameters and center heights from bottom to top rod. If you need any configuration other than those provided in the STL files, simply modify the corresponding parameters in the SCAD file and regenerate your specific STL file. Update 2014-02-25: Just uploaded a slightly improved version which has support layers above the nut cavity and the screw head cavity. This allows for cleaner printing. Update 2016-02-13: If you need a motor mount for you Y-frame, check out my Easy Change Split Y-Motor Mount which can later on easily be removed and replaced without disassembly of the Y-frame.

The source code in the SCAD file is pretty self-explanatory. As an illustration, here is the call to the ycorner() module for producing a Y-corner for the standard Prusa configuration:

ycorner(abt=0,height=[10,20,30,45],diameter=[8,10,8,8],washer=[16.5,20.5,16.5,0],width=25);

The height and diameter parameters specifies the center height and the diameter of the 4 rods (bottom up), the washer parameter give the size of the washer impressions (0 for the smooth rod implying no washer) and the finally the width parameter gives the X-/Y-size of the corner block. The abt parameter is used to specify which part(s) of the corner to build: 0=all (not for printing!), 1=base only, 2=cap only (in print position). Other parameters that can optionally be specified are: top (the thickness of the cap, default=3mm) and gap (the missing slice between cap and base which allows good tightening of the cap, default=0.5mm).

comments.text: Ok,... Im haveing a problem, I tried to change the parameter to have all 8mm rods, distance to center is 10,20,30 and 45 (standars), I change the parameter in the openscad file, then F5, then F6, and export the stl, but all I get is the original setting exports (all 8mm rods and the large smooth rod os 10mm), is there something wrong in the openscad file?
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text: You don't say where you have changed the values of the parameters.  If you just changed the default values of the OpenScad module ycorner() then nothing changes, since in the call to ycorner() at the end of the file the parameters are passed explicitly again.  So you don't need to change the values in the module header, but rather those where ycorner is actually called at the end of the file.
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text:
One question: in my prusa (hephestos) there is just ~1mm gap between the Y carriage and the zip-ties in the corners (when the Y moves that far).
Doesn't the cap hit the Y carriage?
comments.author: MiguelPynto

comments.text: The cap height above the smooth rod is set in the variable "top", which is set to 3mm.  So using the given STL files, you need more than 3mm gap between smooth rod and y-carriage.
comments.author: MiguelPynto

comments.text:
Ok thank you.
How can I add a bigger gap? Is there a piece between the carriage and bearing?
comments.author: enif

comments.text: You could reduce the value of "top" from 3mm to 2.5mm or 2mm to make the gap a bit bigger.

comments.text: Have you looked at the SCAD file?  It's fully parametrized and the main parameters of module ycorner() are the center heights and the diameters of the 4 types of rods. So if none of the provided STL files are suitable for you, just modify the values of the height and diameter parameter (both 4-valued arrays) in the call to module ycorner() - this will automatically adjust the overall size of the corners and the spacing between the rods.
